measured_by: Inventory of Parent and Peer Attachment (IPPA)
justification: “Participants used a five-point scale… to answer 28 items about their relationship quality with their parent… Responses were … averaged to yield a single mean score” – describing use of the IPPA for parent relationship quality.

measured_by: Inventory of Parent and Peer Attachment (IPPA) – Friend form
justification: The same paragraph states participants answered “25 items about their relationship quality with their friend,” using the IPPA, producing a mean friend relationship quality score.

measured_by: Respect for Family Subscale of the Family Obligation Scale (parent-adapted)
justification: In the MTurk follow-up they “modified the Respect for Family Subscale … by changing all items to ask about parents… yielding a five-item measure” to assess obligation to parents.

measured_by: Respect for Family Subscale of the Family Obligation Scale (friend-adapted)
justification: A parallel version “was identical… except all items were changed to ask about friends… producing a four-item measure,” providing an obligation-to-friends score.

“We used a modified version of the ‘hot’ Columbia Card Task to assess how young adults prioritized parents versus friends when making decisions,” positioning the CCT as the measure of risky decision making about close others.

Sample 2 participants also completed “an adapted version of a family assistance task (referred to as the Donations Task)… to characterize how young adults prioritized parents and peers in trade-offs that were certain in nature.”
Supplementary materials note that “the 8-item Brief Sensation Seeking Scale (BSSS-8; Hoyle et al., 2002)” was collected to assess sensation seeking.

measured_by: Domain Specific Risk-Taking Scale – Adolescent version (DOSPERT; health & social subscales)
justification: The authors list “the health and social subscales of the adolescent version of the Domain Specific Risk Taking Scale (DOSPERT)” among the self-report measures gathered to assess real-world risk behaviour.
